    Evolution of Novartis’ Small Molecule Screening Deck Design

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    This article summarizes the evolution of the screening deck at the Novartis Institutes for BioMedical Research (NIBR). Historically, the screening deck was an assembly of all available compounds. In 2015, we designed a first deck to facilitate access to diverse subsets with optimized properties. We allocated the compounds as plated subsets on a 2D grid with property based ranking in one dimension and increasing structural redundancy in the other. The learnings from the 2015 screening deck were applied to the design of a next generation in 2019. We found that using traditional leadlikeness criteria (mainly MW, clogP) reduces the hit rates of attractive chemical starting points in subset screening. Consequently, the 2019 deck relies on solubility and permeability to select preferred compounds. The 2019 design also uses NIBR’s experimental assay data and inferred biological activity profiles in addition to structural diversity to define redundancy across the compound sets.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Plate-based high throughput screening (HTS)(1) is still a major source of small molecule hits in drug discovery,(2,3) despite the emergence of plateless encoded screening approaches, such as DNA-encoded libraries(4−6) and microfluidics-based methods,(7) as well as the advancements in computational virtual screening methods.(8) Therefore, many pharmaceutical companies continue to invest in plate-based low molecular weight (LMW) screening decks and consider them key assets.(9−11)
    Historically, high throughput screens aimed at the largest possible set of samples, irrespective of their quality, to identify all possible chemical matter and remove undesired hits thereafter. Industry-wide learning from property agnostic screens has found that screening of compound collections of poor sample quality (e.g., limited purity) and with poor compound properties (e.g., low aqueous solubility) leads to unsatisfactory results.(12,13) Consequently, most pharmaceutical companies rebuilt their compound management systems to enable quality control of compound collections and curate high-quality and targeted compound sets. This required “individualizing” compound samples from plate-based collections into tubes to allow for selecting single samples through automated high-throughput tube picking and reformatting hundreds of thousands of samples. At the Novartis Institutes of BioMedical Research (NIBR), we undertook these changes of our compound management capabilities from 2008 until 2012.
    These automation advances also enabled a move from classic, full deck HTS to alternative screening paradigms. Today, NIBR project teams commonly screen subsets of the total compound collection (more than 2 million unique compounds) in an iterative fashion. The “full screening deck” has been reduced to fewer than 1.5 million samples by removing low-quality samples or compounds with undesired chemical structures. There are multiple reasons for such alternative screening paradigms. In the past decade, phenotypic screening has again gained increasing importance in drug discovery, with the practical consequence that assays and screening cascades are becoming more complex, thereby limiting the number of compounds that can be screened.(14) Iterative screening can reduce the overall number of compounds screened, save compound inventories, shorten timelines and costs, and more importantly validate and/or optimize assay formats before committing to a larger scale screening campaign.(15,16) More controversially, we, as well as others,(17,18) realized that it is challenging to assess the potential of screening hit scaffolds for optimization toward successful clinical candidates. Consequently, one might argue that the success of hit to lead optimization is more dependent on the ingenuity of the drug discovery teams than the absolute number of hits. A large hit list does not automatically lead to better outcomes, so NIBR project teams may opt to work on early hits from a subset screen rather than invest in more resource- and time-intensive full deck screens. Nevertheless, full deck screening remains an important strategic option for a subset of NIBR projects, including targets (or pathways) with unusually low hit rates, highly competitive targets requiring exclusive chemical starting points, and parallel chemistry efforts on multiple scaffolds, as well as projects with previously truly validated assays and screening cascades.
    Consequently, it has become important to make accessible high value subsets of the compound library. In cases where target and pathway specific hypotheses are available, this is best done through high-throughput picking of customized compound subsets from the tube collection. NIBR’s tube picking and plating capacities allow teams to pick up to 100k compound samples for such screening strategies. However, despite a high level of automation, picking of compounds still involves a significant effort, prolonged timelines for compound access, and higher sample consumption compared to the use of preplated subsets, while offering little added benefit for screening large and frequently used, diversity driven sets (see Supporting Information for detailed discussion). For diversity driven subset screening of >50k compounds, we at NIBR therefore chose to rely on a plate-based screening deck which is produced every 3–4 years from tubes.
    In a classic HTS, where all compounds are tested, the distribution of compounds to screening plates within the deck has little impact on outcome. However, in iterative diversity-driven subset screening (as practiced at NIBR) the right distribution is key to achieve sensible results. As mentioned above, the hits of a first subset screen are normally used to confirm not only the robustness of the assay but also the biological relevance of the screening cascade and even the whole hit finding strategy before subsequent expansion to additional compounds of the screening collection. Therefore, it is essential to arrange the content of the deck in such a way that subsets (defined by diversity and molecular property criteria) can be easily accessed and built upon. Similar efforts have been reported recently by scientists at Merck (U.S.).(19) Their effort was mainly focused on creating small phenotypic screening subsets up to 50k compounds.
    This Perspective describes how we designed and implemented a screening deck for diversity-driven subset screening at NIBR, initially in 2015 and a revised version in 2019.

    Screening Deck Design Principles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To define the design principles for the screening deck, we first assessed its future use. NIBR is a large drug discovery organization with a diverse project portfolio regarding the diseases tackled, the target classes addressed, and the molecular modalities employed. NIBR scientists employ compound screening not only for hit finding but also for pathway interrogation and target identification. The plate based screening deck described here is primarily targeted toward hit finding as most other screening activities require only smaller compound sets, which are easily generated on demand from the tube based collection.
    Hit finding screens can be either truly random or hypothesis-driven based on prior knowledge on target, pathway, or perturbants. Hypothesis-driven screens are best addressed by specifically selected compound sets enabled by advances in in silico methods for compound selections. These selections (mainly project-specific compound sets of hundreds to a few tens of thousands of compounds) are today readily picked from NIBR’s tube store and plated on demand.
    In addition to hypothesis-driven screening approaches, NIBR projects continue to use random screening to discover novel chemical matter interacting with unprecedented binding sites, targets, or pathways. Hit finding project teams often combine both approaches (hypothesis-driven and random) to overcome the limitations and biases (“search under the lamppost”) of virtual screening.(8,20,21) Random screening with the aim to find unprecedented and likely very scarce chemical matter usually requires large numbers of compounds to be tested, widely known as the classic paradigm of HTS.(22) To enable truly random screening for unprecedented chemical matter, we needed to design a deck as chemically diverse as possible and to include the dark chemical matter(23) of our compound collection. Such a deck would serve not only today’s known targets but also the unknown targets of tomorrow. This and the desire of scientists to advance their projects in an iterative way regarding the compound selection as well as the assay formats led us to the decision to focus the design of the screening deck toward diversity-driven subset screening.
    For an “ideal” diversity-driven screening deck, the two most important criteria are, first, it should contain compounds addressing all possible targets and mechanisms of action within a minimal subset and, second, the substance and sample properties should be of highest quality (i.e., no positive readouts of undesired nature, e.g., compound samples that induce protein precipitation). More than 20 years of HTS experience in industry have greatly increased the understanding of these two challenges but also made clear that they are inherently impossible to be completely overcome.(2,24) Nevertheless, the design of our screening decks is based on these two prime characteristics: first, biological diversity as the ability to address as many targets as possible with as few compounds as necessary and, second, optimal compound sample properties to limit positive readouts of undesired nature to a minimum.
    Any implementation of such high-level objectives faces the conundrum that the screening deck design relies on the knowledge generated by historical screening. This has the practical consequence that there cannot be one perfect screening deck design valid for all times and that the composition should be adapted over time to the new data, changes in compound availability, new target classes and modalities, and learnings resulting from its use. Therefore, we decided to define a process in which we would redesign the screening deck every 3–4 years, enabling inclusion of the learnings over time. This process is outlined in Figure 1. The compound-handling setup at NIBR was built according to these requirements and therefore allows redesigning and reproducing the screening deck in that time frame of 3–4 years from the DMSO stock stored tube collection (more details on this can be found in the next section).

    Compound-Handling Technology Enabling the Production of a Designed Screening Deck

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Before 2015, the setup used for maintaining the screening deck was largely as described by Schopfer et al.(25) This setup was designed in the late 1990s and implemented in 2000–2001 to enable large-scale screening of a complete screening deck for traditional HTS (Figure 2). Compounds were solubilized and plated in 384-well source plates for primary screening in the sequence as they arrived in compound management which resulted in a screening deck of up to 1.2M samples. These screening deck plates served as source for all HTS and were renewed continuously from solid samples over a cycle time of ∼6 years. The automated picking function allowed for up to several thousand samples to be picked per week and was designed to enable hit validation of primary full deck HTS campaigns.
    This initial HTS setup enabled effective and highly automated compound screening. However, on the basis of the learnings in hit and lead finding in the following years, it became evident that much higher sample picking would be required to enable a number of emerging concepts mentioned above. The fact that screening plates were produced continuously based on the sequence of incoming compounds had undesired consequences. In particular, it led to a situation in which many samples of high chemical similarity (e.g., from combinatorial libraries produced at a given time) were co-plated on the plates, leading to a low intraplate diversity of compounds. This setup supported only limited diversity selection by plate.(26)
    Due to these shortcomings, the compound management groups at NIBR undertook a major effort from 2008 until 2012 to rebuild their compound logistics capabilities. This included two major aspects: (a) to produce 10 mM stock solution collections for all compound samples (>1.2M) from solid samples that are LC–MS quality controlled and (b) to install automation systems enabling the picking and processing from tubes to microtiter plates of up to 40k tubes in 24 h (Figure 3).
    With the 10 mM stock collection and the automation setup described in Figure 3 in place, a first version of the NIBR screening deck was produced in 2015. In 2019, a second version was created, based on a further design iteration including the learnings and experiences from the 2015 deck.

    Creation of a Screening Deck Diversity Grid

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As described above for the design of our screening deck, we mainly considered two objectives: The first objective is to maximize diversity in the screening deck subsets. Diversity in the bioactivity space is our primary aim. This space is described by the compound’s activity data in all medicinally relevant mechanisms of action, whether these are currently known or not. However, our structure–activity knowledge is incomplete, as we not only do not know the bioactivity of most compounds on the targets that are already characterized but lack the knowledge of entire dimensions of this space corresponding to mechanisms of actions not yet explored. Therefore, relying only on the diversity in the known bioactivity space would restrict us to search only “under the lamp post”. Therefore, we add diversity in the chemical structure space,(27,28) assuming that novel chemical structures also have a higher potential for unprecedented biological activity.(29) Diversity is a collective property of a given subset and cannot be meaningfully assigned to an individual member compound. There is no ranking involved in diversity as coverage of each target is equally valuable in the context of a multipurpose discovery setting. In fact, for phenotypic screening the most relevant targets for modulation of the phenotype are typically not known, so imposing any ranking in the bioactivity space is not expected to be useful. There exists a wide range of descriptors and diversity metrics for chemical compounds, of which some are partially redundant.(30) There is no straightforward way to combine those into one unified metric. The choice made is therefore to use several relevant metrics independently to define compound classes for each metric by clustering. Additional compound classes result from existing discrete compound annotations. Once the compounds are stratified into biological activity and chemical structure classes, the aim of the diversity selection process is to generate minimally sized subsets ensuring a preset minimal coverage for each class. The larger the coverage requirement per class will then translate into an overall higher subset size. Minimizing pairwise dissimilarity of the compounds in the selection is not the aim, as this is driven by the low ranges of similarity values not relevant for inferring biological activity.(31)
    The second objective is the optimization of compound specific and mostly physicochemical properties, where a ranking is well-defined. For example, in the case of aqueous solubility, high solubility is preferred over low solubility given all other properties being equal. As there are a multiple of such properties to consider, they need to be combined into a multiobjective score. Such a score is an individual property of each compound, allowing comparing and ranking compounds on an individual basis.
    To design subsets with maximal diversity and optimal properties, we developed the following process: Given one has defined compound classes for stratification, and a multiobjective property-based ranking, then sampling the best ranking compound from each class results in a subset with optimal properties fulfilling the constraint that all classes need to be covered. This process can be repeated until finally all compounds have been selected, thereby keeping track of the selection round in which a compound was picked. As a result, each compound has two associated properties: the property rank and the selection round at which it was picked. These define a two-dimensional coordinate space, with the property rank as X-axis and the picking round as Y-axis. By appropriate binning strategies, this 2D-space can be partitioned into a 2D-grid of compounds plated together as a group of one or more plates, allowing the scientists to choose from this grid the plate groups for their assays. The sizes of the plate groups (grid cells) are defined by practicalities: they should be small enough such that the screening scientist can generate useful screening subsets and large enough such that the tube picking of each group for the plating remains efficient (see Supporting Information for a detailed explanation).
    By choice of the grid cells corresponding to the first of N selection rounds, a subset focused on maximal coverage can be obtained. By concentration on the grid cells with the top property ranks, a subset focused on good properties can be obtained. The whole concept is outlined in Figure 4. It is possible in this concept to support both subset selection strategies without any requirement for redundant plating. It is also worth noting at this stage that by working with preset and discrete classes as input, the process is agnostic to the exact classification method, and in fact, multiple classification schemes can be used jointly.
    The following sections describe in detail how the multiobjective property ranking is defined, how the compounds are stratified into diversity classes, how the picking algorithm works, and finally how the picking results are translated into plate maps for production.

    Individual Properties for Ranking

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As previously discussed, the new screening deck was designed for diversity-driven hit finding with the main objective to identify bona fide binding partners or modulators of the target or pathway interrogated by the assay. These hits would serve as chemical starting points for the identification of tool compounds or medicinal chemistry programs toward a clinical candidate. Therefore, liabilities that negatively affect the chance of identifying a compound with a desired molecular interaction in the screening process need to be avoided. Liabilities that can be addressed during lead-optimization, such as activity on off-targets or high clearance, are generally acceptable at the screening stage but might be chosen to deprioritize a hit compound or hit class over another. Altogether the requirements for screening compounds are more in line with those for molecular probes, for which solubility and permeability have been pointed out as key properties,(32,33) than with those for drug candidates.
    One key property we use in annotating screening compounds is aqueous solubility, with low solubility leading to a warning flag and high solubility to a positive flag. There is empirical evidence that compounds can act as bona fide hits at a concentration above their reported aqueous solubility. This is counterintuitive, and we attribute this mainly to two factors. (1) The solubility under the distinct assay conditions can differ from the conditions used in standardized HT-solubility assays due to differences in buffer composition. (2) We normally transfer the compounds as DMSO solutions directly into the assay buffer rather than dry them down or perform an intermediate dilution in buffer. Therefore, under cellular assay conditions complex absorption/dissolution mechanisms apply as compounds transfer from DMSO to the nonhomogenous assay environment. Nevertheless, compounds of low solubility (<10 μM) are likely only available at subnominal concentration in most assays. This significantly decreases the chance of discovering them as hits.(34) In addition, low solubility compounds can negatively interfere with assay readouts if precipitating or aggregating at high concentrations.(35) At NIBR, solubility is assessed primarily by high-throughput experimental solubility measurements under equilibrium conditions from dried-down stock solutions at pH 6.8.(36) Such measurements are available for >130 000 samples (7.8%) of our compound collection and can be used for compound annotation. Although solubility assay formats with direct addition of DMSO stock solution to buffer(37) reflect the HTS scenario more closely, it has to be noted here that the majority of the solubility measurements were taken during lead optimization, and the choice of the assay format as well as the compounds measured has been made accordingly. In case the experimentally determined solubility is not available, predictions from an internally trained machine-learning(38) model trained on the experimental data of the assay described above are used instead, provided they have been made with a sufficient level of confidence (see methods in the Supporting Information). Solubility below 10 μM is flagged as a warning (“solubility_flag”) and solubility of >100 μM is used as a positive flag.
    In addition to solubility, cell permeability is a key requirement to observe an intracellular effect in cellular assay systems. Given that cell permeability is not critical for other assay formats, we decided to flag high permeability as positive but not to flag low permeability as a warning. As in the case of solubility, the assessment is based on existing experimental data if available and reliable predictions from a machine-learning model as a second option. NIBR’s databases hold experimental data for >130 000 compounds from at least one of the following three assays: Caco-2,(39) PAMPA,(40) and MDCK-LE.(41) For prediction of permeability, a model based on data from the PAMPA assay was used (see Supporting Information), as this has the largest training set and as we primarily look for passive membrane diffusion.
    Frequent hitters are a problem that has gained great attention over the past decade.(42−44) Frequent hitters can be defined as compound samples, which show up repeatedly as “active” in many unrelated assays. This can be caused by interference with assay readouts, unspecific modification or sequestrations of proteins, or genuine polypharmacology.(45) While true polypharmcoplogy, that is the unselective but specific binding to many proteins, is not a concern as such, it is hard to distinguish this from unspecific frequent hitter behavior. Compounds showing excessive polypharmacology, such as for example type-I kinase inhibitors, are still not very attractive starting points, and therefore, flagging such compounds as frequent hitters is considered acceptable, even more so as these compound classes are typically well-known in advance of an HTS. It is important to note that the frequent hitter character can be due to the compound itself but also due to impurities in the sample originating from synthesis procedures or compound instability. Repeatedly occurring examples of reactive impurities are reagents like acylating agents or metals.(46)
    Here, we identified frequent hitters empirically from the screening history of a sample as described by Nissink et al. based on the number of assays it was screened in and the number of assays it hit without considering assay target and read-out methodology.(47,48) Samples identified as frequent hitters in this way were assigned a warning flag (“frequent_hitter_flag”). It is worth noting here that frequent hitter behavior defined in this way can be partially related to low solubility. While 15% of the compounds predicted to have a low solubility were flagged as frequent hitters, this was only the case for 6% of the remaining compounds, indicating that avoiding low solubility compounds will also be beneficial from a frequent hitter point of view. This is in line with observations made by Guha et al.(37)
    Detecting frequent hitters in this empirical way requires that the sample has been exposed to a sufficient number of assays. Therefore, it makes sense to augment the empirical assessment by substructure filters known to indicate frequent hitter behavior. There is a wide range of publications describing such filters, some of them based on individual assay technology, such as α screen in case of PAINS.(49) In a team of computational and medicinal chemists, a wide range of published(49−59) and internally used filters were reviewed. We decided to exclude the PAINS filter family C(49) in this review since this set is based on very limited data (<15 compounds) and was developed for α screen assays only. Altogether 1270 unique substructure filters encoded in SMARTS(60) notation were reviewed, resulting in a final set of 444 filters that can be used for hit finding and triaging in NIBR. One major reason for the drastic reduction in the number of filters was their redundancy. Since the initial set was collected from many different sources (most of them were also collections of filters published by pharma companies and created for excluding compounds from screening campaigns), some duplicates or slight variations were introduced to these filters over time. The SMARTS representation is quite powerful to describe molecular patterns, but it is also very complex to interpret (compare the visualizations in Figure 5a) and especially complicated when comparing SMARTS against each other.(61,62) Due to this complexity and the fact that the team wanted to include opinions from a broad community of medicinal chemists, several approaches like an online survey and guided discussions were used to define the final set. A similar approach was conducted by Lahue and colleagues at Merck to review substructure alerts.(19) The overall goal of this review was to decide if a filter should be retained for the final set and if so, which severity level it should have, high or low severity or just annotation. The high severity level led to exclusion of the compounds from the screening deck altogether (“substructure_OUT”), whereas the filters of low severity add a warning flag to the compound (“substructure_flag”). In addition, some filters were retained for annotation purposes only to guide project teams but without any deprioritization of the matched compounds. Figure 5b shows the distribution of the filters in the three different severity levels and the number of matches found for them for the molecules of the PubChem(63) version 2018 database. Since compounds can match more than one filter, it was necessary to calculate an overall severity score as the sum of all matching filters (high severity, 10; low severity, 1; annotation, 0). Compounds with at least one high severity flag were excluded from the screening deck. To avoid overpenalizing compounds, it was important to remove redundant filters in the reviewing process. All reviewed substructure filters originating from the literature and in-house are available on GitHub along with a Python script for matching and scoring a list of compounds (see Supporting Information statement).
    These filters also encode substructures to recognize special molecule types like peptides, glycosides, isotopes, steroid, or nucleosides, which were excluded from the main screening deck. In addition to these SMARTS-based filters, we also have defined some additional rules to capture unfavorable structural characteristics: compounds that do not contain any oxygen or nitrogen atom were excluded; molecules that have a very low (<10%) or very high (>60%) fraction of nitrogen and oxygen atoms were flagged.
    Samples of very small structures with a molecular weight of <180 were penalized (“Low_MW_flag”), and samples without an assigned structure were excluded (“no_structure_out”). In both cases the motivation was that very little to no structure–activity information can be gained from these samples.
    Finally, sample quality was taken into account. This assessment was based on LC–MS quality control data of the DMSO stock solutions, which were available for most samples (89%). While samples with a purity below 50% were excluded (“QC_out”), samples with purities between 50% and 85% were assigned a warning flag (“QC_flag”). Samples with >85% purity, but with a mass different from the expected one, were assigned a warning flag as well.
    An overview of all the warning flags assigned to samples included in the 2019 deck is shown in Figure 6.
    A rule-based categorization was used to organize the compounds into three property categories based on the described properties as described in Table 1. The top category “high solubility & permeability” contains positively flagged compounds due to high solubility and high permeability. The second category “neutral properties” covers all compounds without negative flags. All remaining compounds with one or multiple warning flags were added to the “property warning flags” category. Within each category, a prioritization ranking was applied as defined in Table 1.
    Table 1. Compound Ranking Criteria for 2019 Screening Decka
    property categorycontentranking within category
    High solubility and permeabilityNo warning flagsNo further ranking within category
    Two positive flags (good solubility AND good permeability)
    Neutral propertiesNo warning flags(1) Compounds with either good permeability or good solubility and no low permeability
    One or zero positive flags(2) Compounds without low permeability
     (3) Compounds with low permeability
    Property warning flagsAt least one warning flag(1) Only one warning flag and high solubility
    Two, one, or zero positive flags(2) Only one warning flag
     (3) Two or more warning flags: ranked by number of warning flags
    a

    It is worth noting that the ranking defined in this table will produce many ties of equally ranked compounds. This is intentional.

    Bioactivity and Chemical Structure Space Coverage

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    With the property ranking for the X-axis of the grid in place, we needed to define an approach toward diversity coverage for the picking rounds to generate the Y-axis. We used several classification methods that can be grouped into the following categories: individual biological target classes, biological compound profile space classes, and chemical space coverage classes.

    Individual Biological Target Classes

    Bioactivity data on individual biological targets were extracted from our in-house system “hithub”, which contains all in-house bioactivity data and is regularly updated with bioactivity data from major public data sources: ChEMBL,(65,66) Clarivate Integrity,(67) GOSTAR.(68) Two compound classes are defined for each target containing all compounds interacting with this target irrespective of their chemical structure. The first one is a generous definition of activity requiring an AC50 on-target of ≤10 μM, without any further conditions. The second class per target is based on a composite score including both potency and selectivity criteria, aiming at potent compounds with a high selectivity against other targets, combining evidence from multiple data sources.(69,70) The first class will typically contain the second more stringently defined class. Using the more generous classification approach alongside the more stringent one allows identifying compounds for a target in case the second, more stringent rules yield an empty class. In addition, in cases where the stringently defined class contains only compounds with less attractive properties, it may still be possible to select soluble and permeable compounds from the more generously defined class.

    Biological Compound Profile Space Classes

    A complementary approach to grouping of compounds by individual target is the usage of biological profile data across multiple targets or assays. These can be either fully experimentally determined profiles such as HTS Fingerprints(71,72) or High-Content-Screening FPs.(73) As such experimental profiles are not available for all compounds; inferred biological profile from predictive models are used in addition. In our case we used the inferred activity profiles from profile QSAR(74−76) (pQSAR) which predicts AC50 values in a quantitative way. In addition, binary activity prediction from a multicategory naive Bayesian model(77) was used. Prediction profiles were calculated on an individual target basis to obtain the Bayesian activity fingerprints (BAFP) as well as per protein family based on the protein–domain annotation in the pfam database(78,79) domain to obtain the Bayesian domain fingerprints (BDFP). In the latter model, each compound–target pair was expanded to all protein families annotated to the target. The underlying activity data come from the same database as used for the individual target activities. As a fourth set of activity profiles, docking scores derived from docking the compounds into the pocketome(80) were used.
    In order to obtain discrete classes from these activity profiles, they need to be clustered. This was done using the Markov Cluster Algorithm (MCL).(81,82) MCL is a graph clustering algorithm. In the similarity graph for each bioactivity profile type an edge was created between two compounds if the Pearson correlation between two profiles exceeded the cutoff value chosen for each profile type individually to avoid chance correlations (see Table 1 in Supporting Information for the values chosen). Each activity profile data set was clustered on its own; thus no explicit weighting was required. However, the more clusters were generated per profile type, the more compounds are required to be selected per selection round and thus the more implicit weight each profile type gets. In order to balance the weights across the profile types, the same number of clusters of ∼30–50k (to fit the limit of 50k in the first iteration) per profile class was targeted, and the “inflation” parameter of the MCL clustering controlling the granularity was chosen accordingly.

    Chemical Space Coverage Classes

    The coverage of the bioactivity space is the dominant objective. However, there are only assay data for a limited set of biological targets, and novel targets may require different chemotypes. At NIBR, a rule-based scaffold classification has been developed called Scaffold Tree(83) which was subsequently extended to the Scaffold Network.(84) This network was used for the definition of classes purely based on chemical structure. Each (sub)scaffold in the scaffold network forms a class consisting of the compounds containing it as substructure. As larger scaffolds tend to be less informative since they produce too many small classes, only scaffolds up to three rings (not isolated ring systems) according to the definition used in Scaffold Network were included. Singleton scaffolds were ignored.
    Scaffold classification does not work well for structures that are devoid of any cyclic core. Therefore, two classifications based on the extended connectivity fingerprints with a diameter of four (ECFP_4) were added.(85) A similarity graph was computed and clustered with the MCL algorithm. In addition to the MCL clustering, chemical topic modeling(86) was also used. Chemical topic modeling has been adopted from the text-mining field and is able to organize large sets of molecules into specific “topics”, e.g., a peptide topic or steroids or kinase scaffolds. We have seen that the method works well for identifying chemical series in a large set of compounds and that it is also able to find series where the scaffold is slightly modified or disconnected.
    Scaffolds do not convey direct information on 3D shape, and therefore shape classification models were applied. In the 2015 version of the screening deck a shape classification based on the principle moments of inertia of a single, low energy conformation was used following the concept by Sauer and Schwarz.(87) The shape triangle was partitioned into equidistant grid cells which served as shape classes. Such a classification is taking neither pharmacophore features beyond shape nor conformational flexibility into account. We therefore applied a more attractive approach in the 2019 version. The FastROCS software(88) in combination with highly parallelized computation made it possible to calculate a ROCS 3D combo score(89,90) similarity graph, which then could be clustered with MCL in the same way as the biological profile similarity matrices described above. This shape representation does take into account both conformational flexibility and pharmacophore features.

    Manually Curated Classifications

    All of the above classifications were generated computationally and may not always reflect the chemist’s contextual knowledge. Therefore, additional classifications assigned by chemists were used when available. These came from three distinct sources: The first one is the assignment of project codes according to a controlled vocabulary upon compound registration. This may not always describe a homogeneous chemical series but does reflect an anticipated, although not necessarily observed bioactivity. The second one is an in-house database called Compound Series and Favorites (CS&F).(91) This tool implements the concept of medicinal chemistry story-telling as described by Stahl and Baier.(92) A key feature of this tool is to enable medicinal chemists to define chemical series and assign individual landmark compounds and one or more scaffold substructure queries to them. For each series, progress in optimization toward drug candidate is annotated, e.g., through the assignment of tags taken from a large set of standardized vocabulary as well as relationship definitions between compounds or scaffolds. Another key feature is that the medicinal chemists are asked to tag the starting point of a chemical series, which is the screening hit in case the series results from screening activities (Figure 7). In order to derive classes for diversity selection, a membership list is created for each CS&F series in which the individually assigned compounds and the compounds matching one of the series substructure queries are combined. As a third source, compounds from libraries synthesized by combinatorial or parallel approaches are assigned to a specific library code for each library. For each library code there is a class consisting of all compounds annotated with it.
    Table 2. Compound Classes Defined as Coverage Objectives
    typedescriptionused in 2015 version
    Individual biological targets (experimental)TARGET_AC50Compounds with AC50 ≤ 10 μM on given targetyes
    TARGET_SCORECompounds with a target score of ≥4 on a given target(69,70)yes
    Biological compound profile space (experimental)HTSFPHTS fingerprint similarity. p-value derived from Pearson correlation(71,72)yes
    HCSFPFeature vectors from high content cellular imaging assays(73)yes
    Biological compound profile space (inferred)PQSARProfile QSAR including all models on all NIBR concentration response assays where sufficient model reliability was achieved(76)no
    BAFPBayesian affinity fingerprints for individual targets(77)no
    BDFPBayesian affinity fingerprints for targets aggregated by pfam domains annotated to target(77)no
    DOCKING_FPDocking score profiles generated by high-throughput docking against pocketomeno
    Chemical space coverageECFP_4Extended connectivity 2D chemical structure similarity(85)no
    CHEM_TOPICClass assignment generated by chemical topic modeling(86)no
    FAST_ROCSFAST-ROCS 3D shape and pharmacophore similarity(89,90)no
    SCAFFOLDS(Sub)Scaffolds up to 3 rings as assigned by scaffold network(84)yes
    Manually curated classificationsPROJECT_CODESAssignment to project codes by medicinal chemistno
    SERIESManually curated assignment to chemical seriesno
    LIBNAMEAssignment to combinatorial hit discovery libraryyes

    Iterative Compound Selection Process

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As mentioned above, the objective is now to iterate over the classes defined as coverage objectives, pick the best ranking compound sample from each class, and repeat this cycle multiple times. At this stage, the algorithm is agnostic to the source of the classification and class is simply a group of samples. The classes defined are not mutually exclusive in membership, and they may be highly redundant. Such redundancy needs to be handled appropriately, as otherwise highly overlapping classes from different classification schemes would lead to a redundant selection of compounds. Thus, whenever a compound is selected because of its membership to one class, all other classes this compound belongs to are considered as covered as well. This may lead to a higher number of compounds selected per class than targeted at in the selection round due to “collateral coverage”. In order to compensate for that, selection from the affected class is stopped in subsequent rounds until its count is back on target.
    Another point worth considering is the size of the classes. In any clustering, high numbers of singletons and small clusters are expected due to the typical power law distribution of chemical cluster sizes.(94) This would lead to a high number of compounds being picked in the first iterations to cover all clusters. As a consequence, the number of compounds in the first row of the diversity grid would exceed a size practical for screening purposes (we targeted a practical size of around 50k compounds for the first iteration and 50k to 100k for the second iteration, see below). As a compromise, the sampling in the first iterations can be restricted to clusters above a certain minimal size. This is a reasonable choice, as representatives of larger clusters offer more opportunities to follow up the hits of an initial small-scale screen by similarity expansion in an iterative screening process.(95,96)
    Once all compounds have been ranked by property and allocated to coverage classes of different types and the minimal cluster size for each iteration has been defined, the selection algorithm can be run to generate the diversity grid. The flowchart of the algorithm is shown in Figure 8. A step by step toy example can be found in the Supporting Information (Figure S1), and the source code is provided as well.
    In principle, the selection algorithm would allow allocating the compounds to plates in a very granular way, as at each selection round compounds could be allocated to plates in the exact order of the sequence they were picked. However, such a fine-grained plating would be technically challenging and yield no benefit for screening. Experience at NIBR shows that, in practice, project teams prefer to screen plate subsets of stepwise increasing size. The most often used subset sizes are ∼50k, ∼125k, 250k, 500k, and finally the full deck (∼1.5M). On the basis of this, several picking rounds are grouped together in one plate group to achieve the targeted sizes.

    Results: Screening Deck Grids 2015 and 2019

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As mentioned, the first screening deck grid for diversity driven subset screening was produced in 2015 and a modified version was designed in 2019 incorporating the learnings from four years of screening practices at NIBR. The resulting sizes of the plate subsets are given in Table 3.
    Table 3. Subset Sizes of the 2015 and 2019 Screening Decksa
    2015 Screening Deck
    no. of diversity selection roundsABCtotal per row (summation)
    row 1 (01)18k8k18k45k (45k)
    row 2 (02–04)14k11k45k70k (115k)
    row 3 (05–10)10k14k100k124k (239k)
    row 4 (11–35)15k21k208k245k (484k)
    row 5 (>35)71k76k474k621k (1.11M)
    total per column129k131k825k 
    2019 Screening Deck
    no. of diversity selection roundshigh solubility and permeabilityneutral propertiesproperty warning flagsnatural productstotal per row (summation)
    row 1 (01)39k8k4.2k1.4k53k (53k)
    row 2 (02–03)55k20k8k1.4k84k (137k)
    row 3 (04–06)69k32k23k2.9k127k (264k)
    row 4 (07–15)128k83k49k4.2k264k (528k)
    row 5 (>16)111k350k438k4.2k903k (1.43M)
    total per column402k493k522k14k 
    a

    This tables show the screening deck grid. Each row–column combination corresponds to a plate group consisting of one or more screening plates, whose size is given in the table. The row numbers correspond to the iterations that have been made through the compound collection, which are given in parentheses after the row number. For example, in 2019 row 2 contains the compounds that were selected in the 2nd and 3rd pass through all the compound classes of the compound collection. Thus, if rows 1 and 2 are selected for screening, for each class there are at least 3 members present in the subset of altogether 137k compounds contained in these two rows.

    The 2015 version differed from the above-described approach used for the 2019 version. Instead of a coarse-grained classification focusing on the three categories property-based, unbiased, and property warning flags, a more fine-grained property ranking was used in 2015. Multiple objectives were combined by Pareto ranking,(97,98) meaning that in order to achieve a better ranking than another compound, a compound must be superior in at least one objective and not be inferior in any other objective. Molecular weight and clogP were explicitly used in the ranking, with the objective to be as close as possible to, or ideally within, the ranges of MW 150 to 350 and clogP 1 to 3, which were at that time considered to be ideal for hit molecules. Additional objectives used as negative flags were undesirable substructures, poor solubility, and poor permeability; the last two properties were estimated using a combination of experimental data with predictive models as in 2019. It is important to note that in 2015 solubility and permeability were used only to penalize lowly solubility structures but not to give priority to structures with good solubility and permeability over neutral or inconclusively predicted ones. In addition, a frequent hitter flag similar to the one used in 2019 was already in place and was incorporated into the ranking. As molecular weight and clogP are continuous variables rather than discrete flags, they dominated the overall ranking. In order to receive an optimal Pareto rank, both molecular weight and clogP had to be in the ideal range. One key feature of Pareto ranking is also that there is no compensation between the parameters assessed. A tiny increase in molecular weight has the same detrimental effect as the presence of a solubility or frequent hitter flag.
    There were 129k compounds with an optimal Pareto rank, and these were considered as column A. As discussed above, 250k was considered a relevant screening subset size, and consequently the boundaries for the next tier (B column) in the property based ranking were set in a way that forced a size of 250k for the combined A and B columns. All remaining compounds were assigned to the C column, without implying that all of these compounds were problematic. This differs from the 2019 approach, where on the property axis no preset sizes were enforced, but rather the criteria for property categories were rationally set, and the number of compounds for each category was accepted as a consequence of these criteria.
    The property profiles of the subsets of the 2015 and 2019 decks are shown in Figure 9 (molecular weight) and Figure 10 (clogP). The 2015 screening deck grid showed a strong bias for MW < 350 Da and a clogP range of 1–3 in categories A and B, making these compounds almost fragment-like. As a consequence, hits from these categories were mostly attractive chemical starting points due to their low MW and lack of undesired substructures. However, we also observed much reduced hit rates for the categories A and B over category C for the 2015 screening deck, causing concern that the restricted MW and clogP ranges might have led to an imbalance of compound diversity across the deck.
    In both versions of the screening deck the first column consists of highly soluble compounds, either exclusively as in the 2019 version or to a vast majority as in the 2015 version. Detailed distributions of the compounds according to the 2019 solubility and permeability categorization can be found in the Supporting Information (Figures S3 and S4). The difference between the 2015 and 2019 deck is not so much in the fraction of compounds classified as highly soluble in the left column (“A” or “highly soluble & permeable”) but in the total number of compounds that could be assigned to this column. In the 2019 “highly soluble & permeable” there are more compounds than in the 2015 A column, as high solubility and permeability can also be achieved outside the MW and clogP ranges used for the 2015 A column. The overlap between the 2015 and 2019 property column categories is shown in Table 4.
    Table 4. Overlap of Property Categories in the 2015 and 2019 Decka
      2019 deck column category
      high solubility and permeabilityneutral propertiesproperty warning flagsexcluded
    2015 deck column categoryA87404258426693819
    B5367834722311903341
    C15268027795332638525663
    not part of 2015 deck10963816002516425660231
    a

    Compounds without available sample at the design of the 2019 deck were not included in this table, as they have not been rated according to the 2019 screening deck property criteria.

    Primary hit rates are not a good quality measure for screening success,(2) as they often are more influenced by the variable assay robustness against confounding effects than the presence of true hits in the compound set screened. We therefore decided to analyze the distribution of the chemical starting points of medicinal chemistry optimization projects across the grid. We used the CS&F system described above to identify these chemical starting points. We included in the initial analysis the starting points of chemical series that at the time of analysis were either actively pursued or successfully transformed into a development candidate. Ideally such an analysis should be limited only to starting points originating from the screening deck. While CS&F provides the possibility to annotate the sources of starting points by a controlled vocabulary, the level of annotation was not sufficiently complete to take this into account. In the rare case that a chemical series had more than one starting point, and these starting points were from different cells in the grid, only the starting point in the most upper-left direction of the grid was counted. As described above, we use CS&F series information in the selection process for the 2019 grid as coverage objective. This distorts any readout of the allocation of starting points as it forces the coverage of each chemical series in the top row of the grid. Therefore, for the purpose of this evaluation the selection algorithm was rerun excluding CS&F series as a classification method. The resulting distributions can be seen in Table 5. Even in case of a random distribution of starting points, grid cells with more compounds are expected to contain more starting points. Therefore, the relative enrichment of starting points was calculated, which is the observed fraction of starting points divided by the fraction of total screening allocated to each grid cell.
    Table 5. Distribution of Chemical Series Starting Points across the Plate Setsa
    2015 Screening Deck
     ABCper row
    no. of diversity selection roundsenrich% spenrich% spenrich% spenrich% sp
    row 1 (01)3.05.00.90.73.96.43.012.1
    row 2 (02–04)0.00.00.00.01.45.70.95.7
    row 3 (05–10)1.61.43.44.31.412.91.718.6
    row 4 (11–35)1.01.40.00.01.222.91.124.3
    row 5 (>35)0.32.10.85.70.731.40.739.3
    per column0.99.90.910.71.079.3  
    2019 Screening Deck
     high solubility and permeabilityneutral propertiesproperty warning flagsper row
    no. of diversity selection roundsenrich% spenrich% spenrich% spenrich% sp
    row 1 (01)2.77.32.31.23.70.82.79.3
    row 2 (02–03)1.45.32.73.72.01.21.710.2
    row 3 (04–06)1.36.10.51.21.52.41.19.8
    row 4 (07–15)0.76.50.95.30.51.60.713.4
    row 5 (>16)0.53.71.025.60.928.00.957.3
    per column1.028.91.137.00.934.1  
    a

    The % sp columns describe the percentage of the total number of series starting points with respect to the total number of series starting points included in the deck, which is 140 for 2015 and 246 for 2019. Enrichment value are not additive.

    In an ideal case, the relative enrichment should be high in the top left corner and low in the bottom right corner as the recommendation is to preferentially screen the top rows. Somewhat surprisingly, this was not the case. In particular, columns A and B show a negative enrichment of chemical starting points vs column C in alignment with the reduced hit rates observed for our screens. We recognize that 140 chemical starting points are a limited set to draw any conclusions from, but one rationalization could be that our portfolio has evolved to include targeting protein–protein interactions (PPIs) for which larger and greasier molecules are required. On the basis of these observations, we decided to change the ranking criteria for the 2019 version of the grid: high solubility and high permeability were introduced as positive selection criteria for column A (newly termed high solubility and permeability), and MW and clogP were no longer considered directly. However, in order to achieve good permeability and solubility at the same time, lower MW and clogP still appear to be advantageous; the MW and clogP distributions for the first high solubility and permeability column in the 2019 deck are shifted to lower values compared to the other two columns as can be seen in Figure 9 and Figure 10. More importantly, the new design also appears to positively influence the enrichment of the screening deck grid 2019 with chemical starting points in the first two columns and the first three rows.
    With hindsight, one could ask the question why the decision was made to rely so heavily on molecular weight and log P in 2015 since the value of using these properties to predict drug discovery success was already questioned at that time.(99) When we designed the 2015 deck, machine learning models such as those used to predict solubility and permeability were not yet commonly accepted by the chemistry community. This was partially due to the fact that in line with observation at other pharma companies,(100) our models had not yet reached the prediction performance they had in 2019 due to the smaller amount of training data but also because there was still a great level of uncertainty in the medicinal chemistry community about the appropriate usage of such models. Therefore, there was a wish to rely on simpler, easier to interpret rules based on molecular weight and clogP.(101,102) The introduction of a rigorous and transparent internal review process for global machine learning models and clear communication about scope and limitations of each model helped to increase the trust of the medicinal chemistry community in such models and resulted in a wide acceptance of these models for the 2019 version. Another motivation for focusing on low molecular weight compounds in 2015 was that due to the combinatorial explosion of the chemistry space with increasing molecular weight,(103,104) the sampling of the space for larger molecules would be less complete, and therefore it was believed that the chances to find molecules optimally fitting a binding site in this enlarged “haystack” would be lower.(101,105) It was originally anticipated that the A column of the deck could be screened at elevated concentrations in order to also detect the weaker binders expected from this set.(106) Especially for cellular screens, the higher ionic strength resulting from higher concentrations of charged compounds limited this approach in reality.
    Next, we analyzed the frequent hitter distribution (Figure 11). As expected, the percentage of frequent hitters increases from left to right as they were penalized in both versions of the deck. No frequent hitters were present in the first column of both decks. In the B column in the 2015 deck the number of frequent hitters is less well controlled compared to the “neutral properties” column of the 2019 deck. In the 2015 deck the ranking of the compounds was dominated by molecular weight and clogP, and therefore the existing penalty for frequent hitters did not come into full effect. In both decks, frequent hitters were accepted in the C and “property warning flags” sections, respectively. Project teams need to consider this and take special care when hits from these columns are advanced into hit validation. When comparing the upper two rows of the property warning flags column in the 2019 deck with the upper two rows of the C column in the 2015 deck, the 2019 deck has less frequent hitters present there. This might be a consequence of stronger deprioritization of frequent hitters in the property ranking in 2019.
    For the 2019 version of the grid a wider range of computed biological profiles was included, increasing the number of classes to be covered. To keep the size of the first and second row within the size constraints for lower throughput, especially phenotypic assays (as described above), minimal sizes of the classes to be sampled were enforced at 15 and 5 in the initial two picking rounds, respectively. This limits the class coverage in the initial rounds but retains the representation of larger classes. The manually curated classes and the individual biological target classes as defined in Table 2 were exempt from these limitations, as these were deemed highly relevant classifications. As a further exception for the scaffold classification, scaffolds with only one representative were ignored, as these can occur when rings were present as substituents to an otherwise acyclic backbone (for example, oligopeptides with tyrosine or histidine side chains). As the selection proceeded, the classes each selected compound belonged to were tracked. The distribution of the class types during picking can be seen in Figure 12 for the 2019 grid. The chemical scaffolds were the individual class type that contributed most to the selections at all rounds, as the chemical structure is always known, whereas the fraction of compounds that can be linked to biological activity by either experimental data or predictions is limited to the current state of bioactivity knowledge.
    Besides the synthetic compound collection, NIBR also owns a substantial natural product collection. In the 2015 deck natural products have been plated without any structure as one plate group. However, like the synthetic compound collection, the natural product collection is too large to always be screened entirely. Therefore, in 2019, the same selection process was applied, with some modifications, such as the relaxation of a few substructure filters, which are not deemed meaningful for natural products. The much smaller size of the collection made it possible for our natural product experts to review the grouping created by the automated diversity picking and curate it manually. As the collection was overall smaller in size, it was decided to group all compounds together in one row, without distinguishing between the property columns. The resulting plate groups form the column “natural products”. As mentioned, the first screening deck grid for diversity driven subset screening was produced in 2015 and a modified version was designed in 2019 incorporating the learnings from four years of screening practices at NIBR. The resulting sizes of the plate subsets are given in Table 3. Also here the top row contained less problematic structures than the bottom rows.
    NIBR provides a Facilitated Access to Screening Technologies (FAST-lab) program, by which academic partners can access NIBR screening systems and a subset of our screening deck within the framework of a collaboration while bringing their assays and tools.(107) This screening subset consists of 200 000 nonexclusive diverse screening compounds and was acquired by NIBR over the past 20 years from multiple nonexclusive, commercial compound collections. This compound set is called Screening Set for External Collaboration (SSEC). When replating the full deck, we took the opportunity to structure this collection according to the same principle. The one exception was that we did not make use of the manually curated classes that rely on partially proprietary NIBR information. We applied a more stringent minimum class size limit for the first picking round, as in many FAST-lab collaborations the number of compounds that can be screened is quite limited, and we aimed therefore for a smaller first picking iteration. The results are shown in Figure 13 and Table 6.
    Table 6. Diversity Picking of the SSEC Set
    no. of diversity selection roundsC1: high solubility and permeabilityC2: neutral propertiesC3: property warning flagstotal per row (summation)
    row 1 (01)5.4k0.8k0.3k6.6k (6.6k)
    row 2 (02–03)12.0k4.1k1.4k17.5k (24.1k)
    row 3 (04–06)15.0k8.4k3.8k27.1k (51.2k)
    row 4 (>7)23.4k73.3k56.0k151.7k (203k)
    total per column55.8k85.6k61.4k 

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The 2019 screening deck grid is currently NIBR’s primary source for plate-based diversity-driven subset screening. It is used in 50–100 subset screens with greater than 50k compounds yearly across the NIBR sites in a broad set of biochemical and cellular assays. The two-dimensional diversity grid is based on the key characteristics of a screening compound collection: diversity coverage against as many targets as possible and the appropriate compound properties for perturbing the target as desired. This grid of appropriately sized compound plate sets provides flexibility for iterative and subset screening allowing plate set selections based on molecular properties, as well as chemical and biological diversity criteria. The regular reproduction from tubes (every 3–4 years) allows for institutional learning across all hit finding projects regarding both the composition and arrangement of compounds within the screening deck. One key learning from the 2015 screening deck was to rely on solubility and permeability as main determinants for compound attractiveness rather than MW and clogP ranges. This was enabled by the access to high quality predictive models for these properties. In addition, newly available machine-learning models played a key role in extending the diversity selection using categories based on inferred biological activity in the 2019 approach reducing the dominance of chemical scaffold categories in diversity selection. Specifically, adding compound set based clustering of inferred activity profiles enabled us to increase the weight of biological activity information on the selection process. During the use of the 2015 screening deck, it became apparent that continuous communication and education of the screeners and the project teams are critical. Due to the perceived attractiveness of starting points in columns A and B, project teams tended to screen mostly those, irrespective of the target class pursued. However, especially for difficult target classes, chances to identify starting points were likely highest in column C due to the hard cut-offs used in columns A and B for molecular weight and lipophilicity.
    Overall, we believe that our 2019 plate-based screening deck grid is enabling for diversity-driven subset and iterative screening and that the current design provides a well-balanced compound distribution in the screening deck.

    Supporting Information

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

      Source code of the diversity picking algorithm alongside example input and output for the SSEC set on github: https://github.com/Novartis/div_rank. Substructure filters used which have been contributed to rdkit on github: https://github.com/rdkit/rdkit/tree/master/Contrib/NIBRSubstructureFilters.



      All authors are/were Novartis employees, and this research was financed by Novartis.

    Acknowledgments

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Designing a screening deck is a team effort building on the contributions of many scientists. We acknowledge the consultancy from the members of the design team for the 2015 version of the screening deck. We thank the chemists having participated in the review of the substructure filters (Phil Alper, Nicole Blaquiere, Natalie Dales, Martin Eberle, Peter Ertl, Jacob Gora, Brian Hurley, Tom Kirrane, Thomas Knoepfel, Guillaume Lapointe, Philipp Lehr, Richard Lewis, Edwige Lorthiois, Rainer Machauer, Christian Markert, Lynn McGregor, Jeff McKenna, Berndt Oberhauser, Silvio Roggo, Chris Sarko, Tim Schuhmann, Oliver Simic, Finton Sirockin, Aleksandar Stojanovic, Thomas Troxler, Riccardo Vianello). We thank the members of the natural product chemistry team who have reviewed the plate layout for the natural products. We thank the originators of the biological classification schemes for contributing these data: Valery Polyakov and Eric Martin (pQSAR), Yuan Wang (BAFP und BDFP), Paul Selzer and Xian Hang (HTSFP and HCSFP). We acknowledge Bernard Faller, Jörg Berghausen, and Grégori Gerebtzoff for consultancy in the building of the PAMPA model, and Suzanne Skolnik and Stephane Rodde for consultancy in the solubility model building. We acknowledge the internal model review panel for ensuring the quality of these models. We acknowledge the builders and maintainers of our core data warehouses DART/MAGMA/CDF and Hithub for their continued efforts, which made the analyses described in this article possible. We thank all chemists who are contributing their ongoing project data to CS&F, and Werner Breitenstein for the extensive curation of old project data for CS&F. Last but not least our thanks go to the management of Chemical Biology and Therapeutics (CBT) and Global Discovery Chemistry (GDC) platforms for supporting the library efforts.

    Abbreviations Used
    AC50

    half maximal activity concentration

    Caco-2

    colorectal adenocarcinoma cell line

    clogP

    calculated log P

    cpd

    compound

    FP

    fingerprint

    HT-picking

    high-throughput-picking

    MDCK-LE

    Madin–Darby canine kidney cells with limited efflux

    PAINS

    pan assay interference compounds

    QC

    quality control
